description: An introduction to the classical laws of motion requiring a background in calculus. Suggested for students in a pre-health program.
name: GEN.PHYS:MECH,HEAT,SOUND

values.comments:
This is an introductory course in the branch of physics known as classical
mechanics requiring a background in calculus. Students who master classical mechanics
often report that, in addition to acquiring some of the tools they will need for future
studies in science, mathematics, medicine, or engineering, they have also gained a new
appreciation for the beauty of everyday phenomena and have substantially developed
their reasoning skills. Physics 101 lab is a co-requisite.
Some students thought that this course was the “best science course” they took at
Penn. However, others thought that this course required too much memorization and
didn’t focus enough on actually understanding the material in an applicable manner.
Students overall thought that Professor Drndic was an extremely fair professor.
She was “approachable” and willing to alter the class schedule “based on what students
felt worked and didn’t work.” Professor Drndic was quick to respond to emails which
made it easier for students to get extra help. However, some students felt that the course
was disorganized and that Professor Drndic “lacked the ability to stimulate” the students.
She spent too much time on the first half of the course and had to speed through the
second half of the course, which made it difficult for some students to keep up.
Overall, students thought that this was an easy course. They found Professor
Drndic’s grading to be extremely fair. This course is suggested for students in a prehealth
program. It is also good for people “who don’t have a strong physics
background.” It fulfills the physical world sector.

An introduction to the classical laws of motion and thermodynamics requiring a
background in calculus. Suggested for students in a pre-health program.
Students found the course to be “engaging” with “good content.” Students reported
learning a lot from the class, but at the same time found the course material to be a bit
rushed. On the whole, students felt Professor Allen’s “concept tests” were one of his most
effective teaching tools.
Students had mixed opinions about Professor Allen. Most students found him to
be “very passionate” about his class and both “enthusiastic and knowledgeable.”
However, others felt that he was inadequately prepared to teach. Additionally, most
students felt that he was accessible throughout the semester, while others found the fact
that he had no recitation suboptimal.
Many students also noted that exam problems were “much more difficult” than
examples given in lecture and homework. Most students enrolled in this class were postbacs.
